title: Giulio Migliaccio
text:
Giulio Migliaccio (; born 23 June 1981) is an Italian retired <a href="association%20football">football</a> <a href="midfielder">midfielder</a>. He started at lower league sides <a href="F.C.%20Savoia%201908">Savoia</a>, <a href="F.C.%20Puteolana%201902">Puteolana</a>, <a href="A.S.%20Bari">Bari</a>, <a href="S.S.C.%20Giugliano">Giugliano</a>, and <a href="Ternana%20Calcio">Ternana</a> before later featuring for <a href="Atalanta%20B.C.">Atalanta</a>, <a href="U.S.%20Citt%C3%A0%20di%20Palermo">Palermo</a>, and <a href="ACF%20Fiorentina">Fiorentina</a> in the <a href="Serie%20A">Serie A</a>.
Club career.
Migliaccio started his career at <a href="F.C.%20Savoia%201908">Savoia</a>. He debuted as a professional during the 1998–99 season, playing in the <a href="Lega%20Pro">Serie C</a> championship, and making a total of 8 appearances. The following year he went on loan to <a href="Serie%20D">Serie D</a> club <a href="F.C.%20Puteolana%201902">Puteolana</a>. After an excellent season, his performances drew the attention of league leaders <a href="A.S.%20Bari">Bari</a>, who bought Migliaccio ahead of the <a href="2000%E2%80%9301%20Serie%20A">2000–01</a> <a href="Serie%20A">Serie A</a> season. However, he never appeared for the club. The following year he was transferred to <a href="S.S.C.%20Giugliano">Giugliano</a> in <a href="Lega%20Pro%20Seconda%20Divisione">Serie C2</a>.
In 2003, he moved to <a href="Ternana%20Calcio">Ternana</a> to play in <a href="Serie%20B">Serie B</a>. After 39 appearances, in January 2005 he moved to <a href="Atalanta%20B.C.">Atalanta</a> during the <a href="2004%E2%80%9305%20Serie%20A">2004–05 Serie A</a> season. He played three seasons with <a href="Atalanta%20B.C.">Atalanta</a>, collecting 86 caps and 4 goals. His high quality performances during the <a href="2006%E2%80%9307%20Serie%20A">2006–07 season</a> contributed to the club's excellent placement in the league.
Palermo.
Migliaccio joined <a href="U.S.%20Citt%C3%A0%20di%20Palermo">Palermo</a> in the summer of 2007, and was strongly wanted by his former coach <a href="Stefano%20Colantuono">Stefano Colantuono</a>. He was purchased for €5 million, plus the ownership of <a href="Adriano%20Pereira%20da%20Silva">Adriano Pereira da Silva</a>. In Palermo, Giulio became a pivotal player for the club in midfield, and a popular fan favourite, due to his commitment to the club and fighting spirit on the pitch. He was also occasionally lined up as a centre-back, first by <a href="Davide%20Ballardini">Davide Ballardini</a> and then, much more regularly, by <a href="Walter%20Zenga">Walter Zenga</a>, <a href="Serse%20Cosmi">Serse Cosmi</a> and <a href="Devis%20Mangia">Devis Mangia</a>. He was appointed Palermo vice-captain in 2011.
On 28 August 2010, he made his 100th appearance in the "rosanero" shirt: 93 appearances in the <a href="Serie%20A">league</a>, 4 in European competitions, and three in the <a href="Coppa%20Italia">Coppa Italia</a>.
Fiorentina.
On 31 August 2012, Migliaccio moved on loan to <a href="A.C.F.%20Fiorentina">Fiorentina</a> on the last day of the summer transfer window.
Atalanta.
On 11 July 2013, Migliaccio completed a move to <a href="Atalanta%20B.C.">Atalanta B.C.</a> from <a href="U.S.%20Citt%C3%A0%20di%20Palermo">U.S. Città di Palermo</a>. On 29 May 2017 he announced that he would retire at the end of the season.
International career.
Between 2000 and 2002, Migliaccio was called up to the <a href="Italy%20national%20under-20%20football%20team">Italy national under-20 football team</a> on 11 occasions, collecting 4 appearances.
